Dear Ms. Clayton:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed
on June 27, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieve.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
One out of four personnel records were reviewed. One had two
references.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement
signed by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
4

One out of two borrowed bed case records were reviewed. One
did not documentation of a current foster parent/agency agreement
signed by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
R400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
In one out of thirteen foster children updated service plans reviewed,
one service plan dated 10/01/2021 – 12/29/21 was generated on
01/2/2022, 4 days late.
In one out of thirteen foster children updated service plans reviewed,
one service plan dated 12/30/21 -3/29/22 was generated on 3/30/22,
1 day late.

The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not
related to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for their Interim inspection dated
09/20/2021. The agency was in non-compliance with the following: R12312,
Foster parent training, R12418 2 (b) Development of service plan, ISEP 6.30
Supervisory oversight, DHHS Policy FOM 722-08C, Required participation in
development – foster parent/caregiver and birth parent. The agency is in non-
compliance with two of these rules and/or policies.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS:
The agency had three safety alerts.
CONCERN:
The residence does not have a carbon monoxide detector installed.
Due to the age and functioning level of the children, safety is a concern as it relates
to proper storage of medications, chemicals/cleaning supplies.
Cleaning supplies are kept under the kitchen sink in a cupboard and medications
are in the bathroom medicine cabinet. The children placed in the home are mobile
and can easily climb on counters and open cabinet doors, therefore proper storage
of medications and cleaning supplies is a concern.
SOLUTION:
On June 22, 2022, the worker dropped off the medication lock box to the relative.
Photo attached. Worker and caregiver put medications in box together and locked
with key. Caregiver purchased CO2 detector which will be delivered from Amazon
tomorrow and caregiver will send photo of it in the home to the worker. Photo of
order attached. Cleaning supplies in a box in the back corner of the front closet
which stays closed and box is out of sight/covered up. No cleaning supplies under
kitchen or bathroom cabinet.
CONCERN:
There was no smoke detector located in the basement.
This was a scheduled home visit. Prior to the visit, the relative was made aware of
the requirement for the child to be present during the home visit. The foster child
was not home, therefore safety of the child wasn't verified. This safety alert is being
submitted with a request for the agency to verify safety of the home and child.
SOLUTION:
7

The agency foster care worker went to the home on 06/03/2022. The youth was
present. The youth reported he had to work on 05/31/2022 and that is why he was not
there for that visit. Foster care worker informed the foster parent that she needed to
see the smoke detector in the basement. The foster parent pointed out a smoke
detector she had replaced in the dining room. Foster care worker stated there were
concerns of one not being in the basement. Foster parent stated she was told she had
to just put the one up in the dining room because she took it down because it was
beeping. Foster care worker called her director to clarify that the safety alert was in
regard to a smoke detector needed in the basement. Her director confirmed the alert
specified needing a smoke detector in the basement. Foster parent said she would go
buy another one and put it in over the weekend. Foster care worker tested the dining
room smoke detector and it worked. Foster parent stated she has a carbon monoxide
detector in the basement and showed foster care worker. Foster care worker tested it
and it did not work. Foster parent called her neighbor over and he put a new battery in
it. Foster care worker re-tested it and it worked. Foster care worker told foster parent
she needed to put a smoke detector in the basement by 06/06/2022 and that foster
care worker will come back out that day. Foster care worker went out to the home on
06/06/2022 and the smoke detector was installed in the basement at the bottom of the
stairs. Foster care worker tested it and it worked.
Picture 1-Carbon Monoxide at the top of basement stairs Picture
2-Smoke Detector at the bottom of basement stairs Picture 3-
Smoke Detector in dining room.
CONCERN:
The relative refused to comply with a home visit, therefore safety of the home and
child(ren) could not be verified. A safety alert is being submitted with a request for the
agency to verify safety of the home and child.
The following attempts were made to contact the family:
On 5/12/22 at 4:15pm a phone call was made to foster parent and a message was left
on voicemail.
On 5/20/22 at 4:22pm a phone call was made to foster parent and a message was left
on voicemail.
On 5/20/22 at 4:25pm MISACWIS was checked to verify the contact information.
On 5/20/22 at 4:53pm the assigned worker was contact via email.
On 5/20/22 at 6:01pm, assigned worker made contact via email and verified the contact
information for the foster parent.
On 5/20/22 at 7:41pm a voice message was received from foster parent.
On 5/23/22 at 10:27am an attempt was made to reach foster parent by phone and a
message was left on voicemail.
On 5/25/22 at 12:06pm an attempt was made to reach foster parent by phone and a
message was left on voicemail.
On 5/31/22 at 10:38am an attempt was made to reach foster parent by phone.
8

SOLUTION:
Worker made contact with foster parent on 5/31/22 via text at 2:36pm. Foster parent
responded that she was at the doctor's today. Worker completed a facetime call with
the family at 9pm. The youth was dressed appropriately in a dress and pigtails. Foster
Parent apologized for not being able to be present at the home for the visit as
scheduled today. She reports that she fell due to slipping on a deck on Sunday and
was injured. She reports that she currently is on medication and her daughter stop by
the home to help care for the foster child.
Worker spoke with foster parent via phone on 6/1/22 to schedule home visit.
The worker scheduled a F2F home visit for 6/3/22 at 1pm.
Worker completed an announced home F2F home visit on 6/3/22 at 1pm. Foster child
was eating a PB&J sandwich. Foster parent updated the worker on what occurred in
the home and that she was not able to obtain the summary of the visit however has the
voicemail of her Dr. leaving a voice message reminding her the day and time of the
visit. Foster child showed the worker her room. Her room was appropriate and there
were no concerns. She had her clothes folded in her crib however she sleeps on the
queen bed in her room. Foster parent apologized for not being present the other day.
The worker informed her that she will send her the DOC for her to review if needed
however after checking, one is not due until August. They review some of mother's
services and parenting time/ foster parent has to go to her daughter's hair appointment
as she has her wedding on 7/9/22. Foster parent will send the worker the doctor
summary visit that occurred on 5/31/22 if needed.
9

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that Oakland Family Services
will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
